description: From Middle English feble, from Anglo-Norman feble (“weak, feeble”) (compare French faible), from Latin flēbilis (“tearful, mournful, lamentable”) by dissimilation, from fleō (“I weep, cry”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₁-. Doublet of foible.

examples: Though she appeared old and feeble, she could still throw a ball.

entries.meaning: Lacking force, vigor, or effectiveness in action or expression; faint.
examples: That was a feeble excuse for an example.

verbs.description: feeble (third-person singular simple present feebles, present participle feebling, simple past and past participle feebled)
